messages: ac35308fff7abada50397bb69d5658e2 (15:46): The only reason I can think of for having <article> is to prevent accidental search results when the search keywords are spread across multiple <article>s that happen to be shown on the same page
ac35308fff7abada50397bb69d5658e2 (15:48): Because search engines can't know what <div class="some random value representing an article"> means, but they can know what <article> means
ac35308fff7abada50397bb69d5658e2 (15:49): but, well, blah

15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (16:07): (and I'm not saying everything can be solved with microformats)

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:08): 15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd: I think the selection of structural elements in HTML5 (and the lack of footnote, note, comment, etc) is partly justified by http://code.google.com/webstats/2005-12/classes.html - it's trying to cover all of the most common cases, though I guess the cutoff point is largely a subjective choice
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (17:10): is back
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (17:30): 15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd: i think there are several reasons for using elements rather than attributes for article &c
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (17:31): 15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd: (1) it's easier to author and maintain markup with element names instead of lots of divs
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (17:32): 15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd: (2) if we continue reusing div for anything new this way we would end up with DivML 1.0 or something after a while

73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (17:33): 15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd: (3) it prevents the case where an element is both an article and nav at the same time, or where the attribute is placed on bogus places
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (17:33): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: (1) You could keep on adding new elements for anything that is used a lot
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (17:34): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: (2) using new elements breaks in some browsers, while role=... or class=... does not
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (17:34): and I have no 3 yet

73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (17:34): 15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd: (4) it's more performant to process elements than attributes in the general case (look at the headings and sections section for how article is part of the document outline algorithm)
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (17:35): I simply think the amount of new elements is too much
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (17:36): I like <m> and <section>, but I don't think it's worth adding 10 more elements

73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (17:36): (2) i don't think it breaks anything (the content is still accessible as if the tags weren't there, no different from say <label>), it just isn't possible to style in some browsers
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (17:37): Hmm‚Ä¶¬† I remember someone mentioning a workaround for that in fact‚Ä¶ I've never seen it though

73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (17:38): why is it better to use attributes instead of elements? as i said, it would complicate processing, so i don't think using attributes would make the language simpler in any way
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (17:39): one workaround is to use xhtml5 :) another might be to fix up the dom with script afterwards
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (17:40): Hm‚Ä¶ what about the predefined class names, though‚Ä¶ what is the reasoning for not putting them into a separate element?
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (17:40): Hm, they are more like 'properties' of existing elements I suppose
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (17:40): they can apply to multiple elements
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (17:40): yeah
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (17:42): it could be argued that we should combine all sectioning elements (except body) to just <section> and then use an attribute for what kind of section
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (17:43): but i'm not sure what the advantage would be
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (17:43): There's still the difference between <div> and <section> which isn't entirely clear
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (17:44): If you could add a‚Ä¶ say, type="header" attribute to <section>‚Ä¶ the entire page would be <section>s, with very few divs
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (17:44): indeed... i think this needs to be pointed out very explicitly in the spec... in a nutshell div doesn't affect the document outline
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (17:44): so you end up replacing <div> by <section> which is pointless
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (17:44): section is not intended to be a catch-all replacement of div
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (17:44): clearly
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (17:45): but i fear many authors will go "oh, section is the new div, i should replace all my divs with sections!"
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (17:45): q.v. b->strong
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (17:46): yeah
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (17:46): I do believe many div's could be replaced by section's though
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (17:46): sure
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (17:48): here's an experiment: http://simon.html5.org/sandbox/html/w3c-home-in-html5
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (17:49): Yeah, I did something similar with my site a few days ago
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (17:50): Perhaps I simply haven't used html5 enough to judge the use of new elements
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (17:51): What is the reasoning for giving presentational elements a semantic meaning?
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (17:51): there isn't much that can be used today in practice :)
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (17:51): that too
df89bc06dc54f8acd4df00964d498124 (17:52): whow http://simon.html5.org/valid-html5.png with cat inside 8-)
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (17:52): that's probably the biggest reason why I switched back‚Ä¶¬†HTML4 is stable and predictable
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (17:52): 15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd: probably to not upset the semanticists or so
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (17:53): wouldn't it have made more sense to deprecate the elements instead?
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (17:53): that will make em and strong be the de facto italics and bold elements
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (17:53): but they already are
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (17:54): Redefining b, i, small, etc gives me the impression "b, i and small are no longer uncool, and you can use presentational markup again!"
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (17:56): Hm‚Ä¶¬†the use of <article> could actually bring back this old "subscription" feature IE5 had‚Ä¶
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (17:56): see http://lists.whatwg.org/pipermail/whatwg-whatwg.org/2007-January/009060.html

15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (17:57): You'd bookmark a page, then tell IE to check whether the page had been updated or not‚Ä¶ but that doesn't work on dynamic pages unless the actual content can be extracted
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (17:58): which is possible with <article> (anything outside that could be ignored)
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (17:58): indeed
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (17:58): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: ah, interesting‚Ä¶
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (18:00): trying to force authors to use semantic markup doesn't work, they will instead misuse semantic elements for presentational purposes
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (18:01): additionally, semantics is not an end of itself, it's more a means to achieve device independence

15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (18:01): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: that raises the question‚Ä¶ why have four elements instead now (i, em, b, strong) if the more "semantic" ones are supposed to replace the more "presentational" ones?
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (18:01): (or the other way around)
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (18:01): we already have 4. why forbid one pair of them?
da5121879fff54b08b69ec54d9ac2bf6 (18:01): Because they have different meanings.
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (18:02): well, <i> and <b>'s meaning changed
da5121879fff54b08b69ec54d9ac2bf6 (18:03): Yes. To something that makes more sense.

73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (18:03): da5121879fff54b08b69ec54d9ac2bf6: in practice, you can't differentiate between <i> and <em> in an app that extracts semantics, and the benefits of differentiating them on the consumer side is questionable
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (18:04): so i'm with hsivonen (it took me a while though)
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (18:04): How would WYSIWYG editors differentiate between <i> and <em>, and <b> and <strong>?
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (18:04): they don't
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (18:05): So they could use <b> for important text, and <strong> for bold?
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (18:05): That doesn't seem to solve anything‚Ä¶
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (18:05): you can use either for any purpose of why you want bold
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (18:06): you want bold for a purpose, but most authors don't think about the purpose
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (18:06): or they do but they don't want to mark up the purpose
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (18:06): they just hit command-b
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (18:07): and the reader gets the purpose because of the context
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (18:07): search engines can't extract anything useful here
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (18:07): I see‚Ä¶ Why do <strong> and <b> still have different meanings, then?
da5121879fff54b08b69ec54d9ac2bf6 (18:07): In written Norwegian, titles of books, magazines, newspapers, movies, records, TV programs and plays are to be displayed in italics.
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (18:07): 15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd: because Hixie isn't convinced yet, i think :)
da5121879fff54b08b69ec54d9ac2bf6 (18:07): Those italics are not emphasis. And they are not really presentational.
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (18:08): da5121879fff54b08b69ec54d9ac2bf6: indeed
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (18:08): da5121879fff54b08b69ec54d9ac2bf6: but italics there has a semantic meaning‚Ä¶¬†it's not italics because it's pretty
da5121879fff54b08b69ec54d9ac2bf6 (18:09): When we have an element that does the job (<i>), there is no point in requring the author to use <span class='title-of-book'> or some other nonsense.
da5121879fff54b08b69ec54d9ac2bf6 (18:09): 15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd: Exactly.
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (18:09): indeed
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (18:09): seems we agree :)

15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (18:09): seeya

da5121879fff54b08b69ec54d9ac2bf6 (18:10): Which is what the HTML5 spec says. <i> is used to markup ‚Äúa span of text in an alternate voice or mood, or otherwise offset from the normal prose, such as a taxonomic designation, a technical term, an idiomatic phrase from another language, a thought, a ship name, or some other prose whose typical typographic presentation is italicized‚Äù.
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (18:11): nods

15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (18:13): You wouldn't write something like this either‚Ä¶¬† the <span class="noun">title</span> of a <span class="noun">book</span> <span class="verb">is</span> <span class="adjective">italicized</span>.
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (18:13): silly example really

15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (18:14): You just mark up what's necessary‚Ä¶ marking up the title of a book as a separate class doesn't make sense unless you somehow want to do something with a list of book titles
da5121879fff54b08b69ec54d9ac2bf6 (18:14): No. I would write ‚Äú<i>Menneskehetens rikdommer</i> av Leo Huberman er en bra bok.‚Äù

15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (18:15): which is pretty much why I don't like the introduction of header, footer, section, aside, article, nav, dialog, ‚Ä¶ because usually it's not necessary to explicitly mark them up that way
da5121879fff54b08b69ec54d9ac2bf6 (18:16): It might not be neccessary. But it is very useful.
da5121879fff54b08b69ec54d9ac2bf6 (18:17): Especially <article> and <section>.
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (18:17): Apart from less keystrokes and readability‚Ä¶ what is the use of <header> and <footer>?
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (18:17): yeah, I like <article> and <section>
da5121879fff54b08b69ec54d9ac2bf6 (18:20): Standardization. I can tell my web browser to don't bother printing <header>s, <footer>s or <nav>s, because they are not useful on paper.
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (18:20): But you could simply tell your browser to display the contents of <article> instead.
da5121879fff54b08b69ec54d9ac2bf6 (18:22): That is also possible, I guess. But standardization of commonly used classes of elements is useful anyway.
da5121879fff54b08b69ec54d9ac2bf6 (18:23): Both for page authors and browser vendors.
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (18:24): Standardization for standardization's sake doesn't make a lot of sense though
da5121879fff54b08b69ec54d9ac2bf6 (18:25): Standardization makes it easier to write and parse documents.
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (18:26): the use-case of <header> is mainly subheadings (that shouldn't be part of the document outline)
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (18:26): "footer" was a very common class name
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (18:26): shouldn't be here
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (18:26): Ahh, hm
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (18:27): these elements also remove the need for skip links
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (18:28): an <article> element would eliminate the need for skip links as well though
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (18:29): <article> and <nav> mainly
da5121879fff54b08b69ec54d9ac2bf6 (18:31): Sure. But why _not_ standardize the most commonly used classes? footer is the most widespread class on the web.
da5121879fff54b08b69ec54d9ac2bf6 (18:31): http://code.google.com/webstats/2005-12/classes.html
15bc6e4578edf59ea5e901ffb83c59dd (18:32): elementitis :)
